sentence-detokenized: Football - Japan score a lucky win and China lose in a surprise defeat.
Japan began their defence of their Asian Cup title with a 2-1 win over Syria in the Group C winner's draw on Friday.
However, China were not so lucky in their second group league match, suffering an unexpected 2-0 defeat to newcomers Uzbekistan.
In the 78th minute, Uzbekistan striker Igor Shukhbilin made a defensive heading error and lobbed it past the advancing Chinese keeper into the unmarked goal.
In injury time, Oleg Shatskiku ensured victory with a left-footed shot from outside the area.
The former Soviet Union participated in the final of the Asian Cup for the first time.
Despite winning the Asian Games two years ago, Uzbekistan will enter the final as outsiders.
Japan scored two goals in the last six minutes of the game after a defensive error to take the three points from their opening match against Syria.
In the 88th minute, Takuya Takagi lifted Hironari Yanagimoto's cross across goal, which goalkeeper Salem Bitar appeared to have covered, and he drove it straight into the net.
In the last four minutes, Syria made its second blunder.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball into the area, but it was all he could do to divert it into the top corner of Vital's goal.
In the seventh minute, Nader Jokhadar put Syria ahead with a header.
Japan then encircled the Syrian penalty area for most of the match, but rarely managed to break the Syrian defence.
Each time, Bittar makes a fine save.
Japan coach Shu Kamo said: 'The Syrian own goal was lucky for us.
Syria scored early on and then played defensively and adopted the long ball, which made it difficult for us.'
Japan, co-host of the 2002 World Cup and ranked 20th in the FIFA world rankings, are favourites to regain the title at this tournament.
In Group A on Saturday, hosts UAE will play Kuwait and South Korea will play Indonesia.
All four teams are tied on one point apiece after one match.
Rugby Union - Cuttitta returns to Italy after a year away.
The 30-year-old winger will play in Friday's friendly against Scotland at Murrayfield, more than a year after announcing his retirement following disagreements over selection.
Trainer George Coste said he was certain to play on Saturday week and was named in the 21-man squad that lost 54-21 to England at Twickenham last month, with only two players missing from the squad.
Stefano Bourdon was sidelined by illness and Coste announced that back-row Corrado Covi had been recalled to the squad for the England match after a five-year absence from the squad.
Cutitta announced his retirement after the 1995 World Cup. The problem was that he was left out of Italy's squad that played England in the pool stage.
Coste said he approached the player two months ago about a comeback.
'He finished the World Cup in the wrong way,' said Coste.
"I thought it would help if he came back and said he could use it.
I think now is the right time to come back."

Squad Javier Pertile, Paolo Vaccari, Marcello Cutitta, Ivan Francescato, Leandro Mantelli, Diego Dominguez, Francesco Mazzarioli, Alessandro Troncon, Orazio Arancho, Andrea Sugolon,. Masimo Giovane Carlo Cecchinato, Walter Cristofretto, Franco Propriuzzi Curti, Carlo Orlandi, Massimo Cutitta, Giambatista Crochi, Gianluca Guidi, Nicola Mazzucato, Alessandro Moscardi and Andrea Castellani.
Football - Japan win over Syria with late goal.
Scoring two goals in the last six minutes, holders Japan defeated Syria 2-1 on Friday.
In the Group C match, Takuya Takagi's header in the 88th minute slipped under goalkeeper Salem Bitar's body, spoiling an otherwise error-free game.
It was the second Syrian defensive blunder in four minutes.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball into the area, but it was all he could do to divert it into the top corner of Vital's goal.
Syria had taken the lead in the seventh minute from their first real attack.
Ammar Awad's cross from the right was met by Nadel Jokhadar, who headed it into the top right corner of Kenichi Shimokawa's goal.
Japan then encircled the Syrian penalty area and a goal was cancelled out for offside in the 16th minute.
A minute later, Vital made a good save from Kazuyoshi Miura's header, and then blocked another shot from Takagi for a double save.
In the 37th minute, Miura headed a shot from a CK, but Vital made a good save to bounce it away.
However, the visitors failed to equalise in the 53rd minute when Naoki Soma's low ballistic shot was saved by Vital diving to his right.

Football: results of the second round of the England F.A. Cup.
Results of the English F.A. Challenge
Cup second round match on Friday.
Dutch forward Reggie Brincker was set to make his comeback to Sheffield Wednesday on Saturday against Liverpool after FIFA lifted his indefinite suspension on Friday.
Brinker missed the club's last two games after a worldwide ban from FIFA for appearing to sign contracts for both Wednesday and Udinese while playing for Feyenoord.
FIFA's Player Eligibility Committee, meeting in Barcelona, decided that Udinese's document was basically valid but could not be legally protected.
The Commission noted that the Italian club had breached the regulations by failing to inform Feyenoord, who had signed the player.
Brinker was fined CHF 75,000 (USD 57,600) for failing to inform Udinese that he was moving to the club.
Football - Leeds 'Bowyer fined for fast-food row.
Leeds Under-21 England striker Lee Bowyer was fined £4,500 ($7,400) on Friday for throwing a chair at a waiter during a disturbance at a McDonald's fast food restaurant.
Bowyer, 19, who was caught on security cameras, pleaded guilty to a brawl at a London court.
Two staff members who were injured in a disturbance at a restaurant in east London in October were fined and ordered to pay a total of £175.
Leeds had already fined Bowyer £4,000 ($6,600) and warned him that he would lose his place in the team if he repeated his criminal behaviour.
Bowyer, who joined the Yorkshire club in August for £3.5m (£5.8m), was due to play against Middlesbrough on Saturday.
Thursday's games were followed by a basketball championship.
Rugby Union - Little to Miss Campesey's farewell.
Centre Jason Little will miss Australia's final tour match against the Barbarians at Twickenham on Saturday.
Little was replaced by fellow Queenslander Daniel Herbert to avoid the risk of aggravating his knee injury.
Owen Finnegan has recovered from the injury he sustained against Wales last weekend and has retained his position in the back row in place of Daniel Manu.

The Wallabies are targeting a 13-match winning streak and finishing the European tour with a 100% record, but they also want to change their style and give David Campese a fitting send-off in his final match for Australia.
The Wallabies currently have no plans to give the 34-year-old winger a special present, but 75,000 spectators are expected to turn up to see the magic for the last time.
It was Barbarians captain Rob Andrew who doomed Australia in the World Cup quarter-finals in Cape Town, scoring a drop goal with his last-gasp effort.
Andrew is also likely to be the last to play at Twickenham, as "Campo is immensely popular in this country and has been a favourite with the public since he first played here in 1984."
During the tour, Australia won all four Tests against Italy, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, scoring an average of almost 35 414 points per match.

The Barbarians were limited in their player selection due to the league, but they have 13 internationals in their squad, including England full-back Tim Stimpson and wing Tony Underwood, and All Blacks internationals Ian Jones and Norm Hewitt.

Football - Uncapped players called up for Macedonia match.
Romanian trainer Ángel Iordanescu called up three unregistered players on Friday for next week's World Cup qualifier against Macedonia.
Otelul Galati midfielder Valentin Stefan and striker Liviu Civotariu, a defender from National Bucharest, are the new additions to the European Group 8 clash in Macedonia on 14 December.
Iordanescu says he chose them because of their good performances in the national championships, where National Bucharest and Otelul Galati are in third place."
I think it is fair to give them a chance," he told reporters.
League winners Steaua Bucharest finished bottom of their group in the Champions League European Cup, leaving them with only two members.
Adrian Ilie, an attacking midfielder who has recently moved from Steaua to Turkish side Galatasaray, was sidelined due to two yellow cards for foul play.
Defenders: Dan Petrescu, Daniel Prodan, Anton Dobos, Cornel Papula, Liviu Chobotariu, Tibor Selimes, Irian Filipescu.

The Football Championship semi-final, first leg match was played on Thursday.
Cricket - Lara endures another miserable day.
Australia put Brian Lara out of his misery as they beat West Indies by five wickets in the World Series opening limited overs match on Friday.
Lara, who was disciplined for misconduct on Wednesday, was sent off for five points, compounding his tour blunder.
Australia, who lead the five-match Test series 2-0, snapped a one-day six-match losing streak by outscoring West Indies' total of 172 all out by eight balls.
All-rounder Greg Blewett led his side to a comfortable victory, scoring 57 unbeaten off 90 balls to the delight of a crowd of 42,442.
Blewett, the star of the match, took the wicket at 70-2 and continued to play dangerously for 129 minutes, hitting three fours.
He added 71 runs in 85 balls thanks to a crucial fifth-wicket partnership with fellow all-rounder Stuart Law (21).
Lara looked out of sorts during her brief stay at the crease until she was easily caught by Shane Warne at midwicket.
West Indies Tour Manager Clive Lloyd has apologised for Lara's behaviour on Tuesday.
He (Lara) told Australian coach Geoff Marsh that wicketkeeper Ian Healy was not welcome in the visitors' dressing room.
The Melbourne crowd were clearly angered by the incident and shouted loudly at the West Indies vice-captain as he walked towards the centre.
Shivnarine Chanderpaul, also a left-hander, was not handicapped by a foot injury and supported the innings with 54 runs.
Chanderpaul suffered a physical injury when rushing back to the crease to avoid a run-out and had to rely on runners for most of the innings.
Pakistan, which arrives in Australia later this month, is the other team competing in the World Series tournament.

Cricket - Lara faces more hardship on Australian tour.

West Indies batsman Brian Lara, who had already been punished for misconduct after being hit in the first limited overs match against Australia on Friday, has been dealt a further blow on the Australian tour.
Lara's anger at Australian wicketkeeper Ian Healy, who received a harsh reprimand from his own tour management, led to him scoring five runs and prolonging his poor form with the bat.
The West Indies vice-captain struggled with his timing during his 36-minute stay at the crease and the ball from medium pacer Tom Moody flew straight to Shane Warne at midwicket.
West Indies were 53 for 2 in 15 overs at the Melbourne Cricket Ground when play was suspended due to rain after captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and elected to bat.
Lara's outburst three days ago clearly antagonised a section of the Australian public.
A loud cheer went up from a section of the audience as they headed for the wicket.
On a number of occasions during the innings, the crowd joined together to repeat obscene chants against him.
Tour manager Clive Lloyd apologised on Wednesday for Lara's behaviour when he confronted Australian coach Geoff Marsh in the opposition dressing room to protest his exit in Tuesday's second Test.
Mr Lloyd did not specify what form of disciplinary action would be taken.
Lara, who holds the record for the highest score in Test and first-class cricket, was unhappy with Healy's role in the incident and questioned whether the ball was carried to the Australian keeper.
Australia took a 2-0 lead in the five-Test series with a 124-run win at the Sydney Cricket Ground after Lara failed in both innings.
Lara has yet to record a century since the West Indies arrived in Australia five weeks ago.
Both West Indies and Australian team management deny the incident and stress that it has no negative impact on relations between the two countries.
Pakistan, which arrives next week, is the third team in the World Series triangular tournament.
Cricket - West Indies bat after winning the toss.
West Indies captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and elected to bat in the first match of the World Series Limited Overs match against Australia at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on Friday.
